title: Bottom sheets
description: Bottom sheets are surfaces containing supplementary content,  anchored to the bottom of the screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are two types of bottom sheets: standard and modal.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Standard bottom sheet
2. Modal bottom sheet
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of standard bottom sheet modal bottom sheet

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – Sheets: bottomAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposePlanned
FlutterIn progress
WebNot planned
Takeaways

• Bottom sheets are supplementary surfaces primarily used on mobile
  • Bottom sheets display content that complements the screen’s primary content. They can be dismissed in order to interact with the underlying content.
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Shape: Bottom sheets have a 28dp top corner radius
  • Layout: New max-width of 640dp and an optional drag handle with an accessible 48dp hit target

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheets have an updated corner radius and new maximum width.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents
Bottom sheets
Color
Layout
Bottom sheets
Modal bottom sheets are above a scrim while standard bottom sheets don't have a scrim. Besides this, both types of bottom sheets have the same specs.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Bottom sheets display supplementary content and actions on a mobile screen.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheet containing contacts and applications.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Bottom sheets are a versatile component that can contain a wide variety of information and layouts, including menu items (in list or grid layouts), actions, and supplemental content.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheet with menu items in a list.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy
A container is the only required element of a bottom sheet. Bottom sheet layouts can vary widely to support the types of content they contain.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
  2. Drag handle (optional)
  3. Scrim (modal only)

contentChunks.htmlValue: Container

Bottom sheet containers hold all bottom sheet elements. Their size is determined by the space those elements occupy.

The container is the only required element of a bottom sheet. All other elements are optional.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheets are flexible containers that adapt to their content and available space.

contentChunks.htmlValue: List items (optional)
Lists are a continuous group of text or images. List items can include label text, icons, and text buttons, among other elements.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheet containing a list with icons.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividers (optional)
Dividers can be used to separate related content in bottom sheets.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheet with a divider separating types of actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Media (optional)

Thumbnail
Bottom sheets can include thumbnails for an avatar or logo.

Image
Bottom sheets can include photos, illustrations, and other graphics, such as weather icons.

Video
Bottom sheets can include video.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheets can contain thumbnails, images, and video.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Standard bottom sheets

Standard bottom sheets co-exist with the screen’s main UI region and allow for simultaneously viewing and interacting with both regions, especially when the main UI region is frequently scrolled or panned.

Use a standard bottom sheet to display content that complements the screen’s primary content, such as an audio player in a music app.

contentChunks.footer: The music player in this standard bottom sheet allows people to control their music while browsing albums.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
At full-screen height, standard bottom sheets contain a collapse icon in an app bar to return to their initial position.

Standard bottom sheets can contain supplementary content that continues below the screen, such as location information over a map.

contentChunks.footer: A bottom sheet brought to full-screen height includes a collapse affordance to return to its initial position.
Standard bottom sheets are elevated above the main UI region so their visibility is not affected by panning or scrolling.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Modal bottom sheets

Like dialogs, modal bottom sheets appear in front of app content, disabling all other app functionality when they appear, and remaining on screen until confirmed, dismissed, or a required action has been taken.

contentChunks.footer: A modal bottom sheet must be interacted with or dismissed. Its blocking behavior makes it suitable for a menu, such as in this files app, to help people focus on their available choices.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use a modal bottom sheet as an alternative to inline menus or simple dialogs on mobile, especially when offering a long list of action items, or when items require longer descriptions and icons.

Modal bottom sheets are used in mobile apps only.

contentChunks.footer: Modal bottom sheets can be used instead of menus to present additional actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Visibility

To provide access to its top actions, the initial vertical position of modal bottom sheets is capped at 50% of the screen height.

Modal bottom sheets whose contents exceed 50% of the screen height can then be pulled across the full screen and scrolled internally to access their remaining items.

contentChunks.footer: The initial vertical position of modal bottom sheets can't exceed 50% of the screen height.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Modal bottom sheets appear when triggered by a user action, such as tapping a button or an overflow icon. They can be dismissed by:

  • Tapping a menu item or action within the bottom sheet
  • Tapping the scrim
  • Swiping the sheet down
  • Using a close affordance within the bottom sheet’s top app bar, if available

Display a close affordance in a full-screen modal bottom sheet.

contentChunks.footer: Tapping the scrim dismisses a modal bottom sheet.
A modal bottom sheet can be dismissed by swiping the sheet down.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout
Mobile
On mobile devices, bottom sheets extend across the width of a screen and are elevated above the primary content.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheets should extend to the width of the screen on mobile.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Tablet

For larger screens, bottom sheets have a default max-width to prevent undesired layouts and awkward spacing. However, this can be overridden if needed. For more complex tasks and flows, consider using a non-transient surface such as a floating sheet.

contentChunks.footer: Tablet bottom sheets have a max width that can be overridden.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Desktop
A bottom sheet on mobile can be swapped for a side sheet on desktop that shows supporting content on larger screens.

contentChunks.footer: Side sheets can contain the same content as bottom sheets and may be more suitable for desktop.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Bottom sheets can offer an expansion option where the sheet is fully raised and toggled between a collapsed and expanded state. This provides a more predictable footprint of the sheet, and can be set by the system or toggled by the user.

contentChunks.footer: A bottom sheet for sharing can appear fully raised if needed.
Alternately, a bottom sheet for sharing can appear collapsed for a more focused set of actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Custom positioning
The optional drag handle provides an affordance for custom sheet height, or for a quick toggle through preset heights.

contentChunks.footer: The optional drag handle provides an affordance for custom sheet height, or for a quick toggle through preset heights.
A bottom sheet can automatically resize to another height after interacting with the drag handle.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Scrolling
Bottom sheets can be vertically scrolled, independent of the rest of the screen’s content.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom sheets should be scrollable when their content exceeds the initial viewable height.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to

  • Resize bottom sheets without having to rely on touch gestures

<h2><span data-buffer="<!--(figma)(/figma)-->">Interaction & style</span></h2>

Touch target area

The top 48dp portion of the bottom sheet is interactive when user-initiated resizing is available and the drag handle is present.

contentChunks.footer: To ensure touch target accessibility, the top portion of a bottom sheet can be reserved for resize interactions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Initial focus

The optional drag handle can be focused in the tab order and interacted with using non-touch inputs, such as keyboard or switch controls.

contentChunks.footer: Visible focus shown on the drag handle affordance

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on drag handle
Space / EnterToggles between available heights
Labeling

The accessibility role for a bottom sheet is "bottom sheet." When a bottom sheet is triggered and focus is moved to the first element in it, a screen reader will announce "bottom sheet" due to its role.

contentChunks.footer: For screen reader users, the role will be announced as "bottom sheet."
